name: 1,2,3,5-Tetrachlorobenzene
source: Abraham M.H. and Acree Jr. W.E. The solubility of liquid and solid compounds in dry octan-1-ol. Chemosphere (2013)

name: 1,2,3,5-Tetrachlorobenzene
source: Abraham M.H. and Acree Jr. W.E. The solubility of liquid and solid compounds in dry octan-1-ol. Chemosphere (2013)
Reason: The basic unit for the prediction is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The presence of chlorine atoms tends to increase the melting point due to their electronegativity and mass, which leads to stronger intermolecular forces such as dipole-dipole interactions. Each chlorine substituent on benzene is expected to increase the melting point. Considering each Cl adds approximately +15 to the melting point (based on monosubstituted chlorobenzenes), with four Cl substituents, the increase should be +60°C. However, there is also a steric effect due to the 1,2,3,5-substitution pattern which might slightly reduce the melting point from what would be expected if the chlorines were not adjacent to each other. Therefore, the cumulative effect of the four chlorine atoms may be slightly less than 4 times the effect of one chlorine atom.
